description.p: A human in tattered clothes delivers a flurry of punches to a thug in a dark alley. A half-orc with scarred fists grapples a foe to the ground, striking with ruthless precision. An elf in loose wraps dances around her opponent, landing devastating kicks. These are Street Fighters, warriors forged in the crucible of urban brawls and underground cages. Masters of unarmed combat, they wield their bodies as weapons, blending raw power, cunning, and instinct. Whether a disciplined boxer, a scrappy street dog, a fluid Muay Thai artist, a brutal MMA-inspired hound, or a savage beast, Street Fighters thrive in chaos, facing danger with grit and skill.

Street Fighters excel in close-quarters combat, using fists, kicks, elbows, and improvised weapons. They are not bound by formal training but by hard-earned experience in unpredictable environments. Each Street Fighter specializes in a unique style, from stunning punches to tactical improvisation, making them versatile in any brawl.

Not every street thug or tavern brawler is a Street Fighter. Only those who have endured countless fights, honed their instincts, and mastered their craft rise to this level. They might be pit fighters, gang enforcers, or self-taught survivors, but all share a knack for turning any situation to their advantage.

Consider your character’s origins: Where did you learn to fight? In a boxing ring, a back alley, or an underground cage? What drives you—revenge, survival, or glory? Were you mentored by a grizzled veteran, or did you claw your way up through sheer will? Your scars, tattoos, or fighting stance might reflect your past, shaping how you approach combat and the world.

Make Strength or Dexterity your highest ability score, depending on whether you focus on powerful strikes or agile maneuvers. Constitution should be your next-highest score for durability. Choose the Urchin or Criminal background.
As a Street Fighter, you get the following class features.

Hit Dice: 1d10 per gunslinger level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 10 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per gunslinger level after 1st

Armor: Light armor
Weapons: Simple weapons, improvised weapons

Saving Throws: Strength, Constitution
Skills: Choose two from Acrobatics, Athletics, Insight, Intimidation, Perception, Stealth, and Survival
You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: (a) a set of common clothes or (b) padded armor
(a) a shortsword, (b) two daggers or (c) nothing
(a) a sling with 20 stones or (b) 10 throwing knives (use dagger stats)
(a) a burglar’s pack or (b) an explorer's pack

description.p: At 1st level, your practice of iron fists gives you mastery of combat styles that use unarmed strikes and monk weapons, which are shortswords and any simple melee weapons that don’t have the two-handed or heavy property.
You gain the following benefits while you are unarmed or wielding only monk weapons and you aren’t wearing armor or wielding a shield:

ul.li: You can use Dexterity instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls of your unarmed strikes
You can roll a d6 in place of the normal damage of your unarmed strike. This die changes as you gain Street Fighter levels, as shown in the Iron Fists column of the Street Fighter table.

sheet.description: Your unarmed strike does {{iron fists:amount}}d{{iron fists:dice}}+{{iron fists:damage}} damage. You can use Strength or Dexterity for these attacks.

description.p: While you are not wearing any armor, your Armor Class equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Constitution modifier.

sheet.description: While you aren’t wearing armor, your AC equals {{ac:tough skin street fighter}}.

description.p: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you strive to emulate in your combat styles and techniques. Your archetype grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 10th, 15th, 18th and 20th level.

Your experience in the back streets and underground has made you a dangerous fighter. What you gain from this dangerous experience is called Threat Points. Your Street Fighter level determines the number of points you have. At the start of 3nd level you choose 3 threat moves. You learn two additional threat moves of your choice at 6th, 10th, 15th, 18th and one at 20th level. Each time you learn threat moves, you can also replace two threat move you know with a different one.
Saving Throws. Some of your maneuvers require your target to make a saving throw to resist the maneuver’s effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

center.p: Maneuver save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier.

sheet.description: You learn maneuvers that are called threat moves. You have {{threat moves:amount}} threat points.

description.p: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th level, 12th level, 16th level, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As usual, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
At 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once when you take the attack action on your turn.
The number of attacks increases to three when you reach 11th level in this class.

sheet.description: You can attack twice, instead of once when you take the attack action on your turn.
You can attack three times, instead of once when you take the attack action on your turn.

description.p: Your Strength modifier is added to Intimidation checks. Additionally, when you deal damage with an unarmed strike, you can make an Intimidation check as a bonus action

sheet.description: When you deal damage with an unarmed strike, you can make an Intimidation check as a bonus action

description.p: Your unarmed attack damage roll is always calculated one level higher (e.g. your 1st level damage die is 1d8, 5th level damage die is 1d10, 11th level damage die is 1d12 and 17th level damage dice is 2d8). However, you have disadvantage on Charisma (Persuasion) checks when interacting with people who are aware of your reputation or unfamiliar with your appearance.

description.p: When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can spend 2 Threat Points to force the creature to make a Constitution saving throw (DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier). On a failure, the creature has a disadvantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws, and its speed is reduced by 10 until the end of its next turn.

On a failure, the creature has a disadvantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws, and its speed is reduced by 10 until the end of its next turn.

description.p: When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can spend 1 Threat Point to force the creature to make a Constitution saving throw (DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier). On a failure, the creature can’t speak or cast spells with verbal components until the end of its next turn.

description.p: As a reaction when a creature attacks you, you can spend 2 Threat Points to add +2 to your AC against that attack. If the attack misses, you make an unarmed strike to the creature and the creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier) or be frightened until the end of its next turn.
